entry.title: Struggles of the Introverts in an Extroverted Society
entry.content:

Parenting in 1950s believe that children who are quiet and solitary are unacceptable and that gregariousness are ideal for both genders. The quiet kids were singled-out as problem cases in school and were shunned for their solitary and serious demeanor. The parents of these introverted children mean well and were only preparing their kids for higher education and the â€œreal world.â€

entry.title: Extrovert vs Introvert Leadership
entry.content:
Some of the first things that comes to mind to most of us when we think of leadership are gregariousness, solid people skill, electrifying speeches, life of the party, etc., and that quite leadership is an oxymoron. Itâ€™s only natural that we require these traits from a good leader as our society #leans toward extroverted ideals. We strive to be the Steve Jobs or the Martin Luther King, Jr of the world and less like Steve Wozniak or Rosa Parks, though the latter are just as exceptional, if not more, than the former.

A research from a management professor at Wharton who consulted Fortune 500 executives and military leaders, Adam Grant, dug deeper into the correlation between extroversion and leadership, and found that the existing research failed to differentiate among situations what leaders might face. Grant noticed that the studies focused more on what our perception of a good leaderâ€“rooting from our societal idealsâ€“rather than the actual result. Grant believes that certain organization or context calls for an introverted leadership rather than an extroverted approach.

His hypothesis was that extroverted leaders are better suited to lead passive followers, and introverted leaders are more effective with proactive team. â€œIntroverts are uniquely good at leading initiative-takers. Because of their inclination to listen to others and lack of interest in dominating social situationsâ€, says Adam Grant, â€œâ€¦Having benefited from the talents of their followers, they are likely to motivate them to be even more proactive.â€ On the other hand, extroverts â€œcan be so intent on putting their own stamp on events that they risk losing othersâ€™ good ideas along the way and allowing [followers] to lapse into passivity1â€, wrote Susan Cain. However, extrovertâ€™s natural ability to inspire are more effective on getting things done form passive followers.

In conclusion, Grantâ€™s research suggest that introverted leaders are better off sticking to what they do naturally and should not be construed as anything less of a what we think a leader should be. In contrast, extroverts â€œmay wish to adopt a more reserved, quiet style,â€ as Grant stated, and should learn to listen more to give the quite-oriented the chance to speak at their speed.

entry.title: The Great Divide in Personality
entry.content:
Carl G. Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist who founded analytical psychology, distinguish the great divide between two personalitiesâ€“extroverts, the â€œman of actionâ€, and introverts, the â€œman of contemplationâ€â€“our society has been geared towards extroversion ideals. In the #Culture of Personality, we follow those who are confident and assertive than those who are reticent and unassuming 1. Researchers estimates 50-70% that make up the population are extroverts, whilst 16-50% were introverts. 2

Of course, personality has different flavors; its not always yin and yang of personality. If you take the The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) test, there are actually 16 types of personalities based on the theory of psychological types explained by Jung 3. The purpose of this test is to make the type theory accessible to individuals and groups, and to help individuals find their a suitable profession for their type.

Although MBTI is a paid service and is restricted for use only to certified professionals 4, there is a free online personality test similar to MBTI that is more accessible to anyone who desires to know their type 5.

entry.title: Culture of Character to Culture of Personality
entry.content:
In the Culture of Personality, people focus on how others perceived them and aspire to be bold and entertaining. â€œThe social role demanded of all in the new Culture of Personality was that of a performer,â€ Warren Sussman, influential cultural historian, famously wrote. â€œEvery American was to become a performing self.â€ As opposed to the Culture of Character where â€œthe ideal self was serious, disciplined and honorableâ€. People value not so much as the impression they make in public but as how they behave in their privacy. The word personality werenâ€™t even invented until the eighteenth century, and the idea of â€œhaving a good personalityâ€ was not widespread until the twentieth. 1

A shift from the Culture of Character to the Culture of Personality brings new wave of cultural ideals# from which we would never quite recover.

entry.title: Step Four: Have a Plan
entry.content:
The final step of #The Framework for Changing Habits1, is to establish a plan of action to begin to shift your behavior.

The hardest part of habit change, even equipped with the knowledge of your cue, is making the conscious effort to steer away from doing your routine. Sometimes you forget and sometimes you just donâ€™t have the willpower to defy your urges. Hence, study after study concluded that having a plan is the easiest way to accomplish something. Not just having a plan in mindâ€“itâ€™s as if writing in waterâ€“but having it in a piece of paper is more powerful.

Say, through reward experimentations, your finding indicates you quench your sweet tooth by eating a chocolate bar, and a working alternative is to bite an apple instead. Your plan of action should be: â€œWhenever I feel the need to take a chocolate bar, I will grab an apple instead.â€ Better, when you know what time you usually snack: â€œAt 4:30, I will go to the cafeteria and grab a fruitâ€.

Specificity is key. The more specific your are with your plan, the easier it is to follow.

Additionally, plan ahead for when you succumbed to your urges. After all, we are creatures who act according to our urges. Itâ€™s how we survive. You may choose to punish yourself for it, but it is better yet have a plan of action for when you capitulate.

Sometimes, you wonâ€™t have enough willpower to stick to your rule after a long day of work. It is more acceptable to compensate rather than to skip and declare a â€œcheat dayâ€â€“we all know how it ends. For instance, instead of eating a fruit you grabbed a cookie. You may write on your plan: â€œWhen Iâ€™m tempted to grab a cookie and cannot resist anymore, I will only eat half of it.â€ Still, you satisfied your cue to eat something sweet but itâ€™s a win nonetheless, because you resisted to eat the whole thing and abided by your plan.

You may add a few more rules to your list, but be sure to make it simple, concise, actionable and specific. Not too complicated of a plan to overwhelm yourself, but not too simple that you can ignore it.
